Hello,
Alas, I did not invent this very fascinating dragonfly toy which balances on the fingertip (or other small areas). I think it's a traditional toy usually made of wood or bamboo.
So I tried to adapt it for 3D printing.
This version consists of 4 simple parts to be printed in several colors and can be build without glue.
IMPORTANT: If you want that the balance works well, the object must be 100% full. (But as it is relatively thin, it does not take much matter).
It could be printed without raft or support.

Have fun with this strange object.
Thank you.

This was my first experiment with making a gearbox for a hobby motor with a 1.5mm shaft. It worked surprisingly well, though not perfect by any means. It seems like spacing needs to be a little tighter in some areas, and the structure needs to be reinforced for stability.

You can affix the gears by sliding a straightened paperclip through the mounting holes. They happen to be 1.5mm, same as the motor shaft diameter which made the holes nice and consistent.

There still isn't a fixture for extending the final gear to a wheel

The gear ratio winds up being 1 to 125, which is still pretty fast but vastly improves the torque on small motors so they will actually push a light amount of weight. I still have yet to test it with an Arduino Uno, but my goal is to use two of these motors with gearboxes to push one of those around. It will be part of a light-following robot that I'm going to have people build as part of an Arduino class at Port City Makerspace.

Link to Tinkercad
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8PqlkRxSzdt

Here's a bin for your tiniest of treasures! It fits in the palm of your hand and will hold precious items. Decorate it with markers and prints to look like it lives on the street. The dumpster prints in several pieces all without support and needs a little glue to assemble. Simonkangiser.com

Printing the dumpster is fairly straight forward. Because of the small nature,the casters and bar work best printed with a brim. If the piece has a number in front of it, you print that many of the piece.
When you glue the casters in place, there is a flat side on the tapered peg that corresponds to a flat in the bottom of the bin. If you look at the model before printing, you will see what I mean. The casters will fit in the holes in any direction, but they sit the best if these flats are lined up. I used a sewing pin inserted in the hole for an added detail.
Each sleeve is printed flat and the 3 parts should be kept together as one piece. The plastic between the pieces is a hinge and allows you to easily fold them into the required shape. Fold it up and glue it in place on each side of the bin.
The hinges part will slide down on top of the bin and stop on top of the corner guards. The holes in the hinges will probably have to be drilled to make them round to accept the bar. Put the lids in place and slide the bar through. I glued the bar in place with a drop of glue on the tab where it touches the corner of the bin. The bar can be swapped out for a piece of wire if you like.
I included a photo of a version of the bins. Originally, I only made the lids and casters for the sculpture and made the rest of the body from metal. I decided it would be fun to make the complete dumpster to print. Enjoy:) Instagram:Simonarri

When the wind blows, the rotor blades and so the shaft start to turn. On the shaft there are some levers which are lifting the wheight on it. When the levers turn around the weights fall down and impact onto the tube. This impact makes a noise.

For example you can use it to make nice noises in the wind or to keep away animals from your garden plants.

You can see a VIDEO here:
https://youtu.be/CQovZbifR9Y

If you need additional blades visit:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1498345
Cooasty made a lot different shapes you can use.

Have fun!

You can choose between the traditional straight rotor blades and the enhanced blades, for landscapes with low wind.

You need three M3 Screws (>5mm) and one M5 (~12mm) screw and three pins (d5x8 mm) you can print them too but i took some ready shafts.
I used two ball bearings. (22x8x6mm | Dxdxw) = Bearing No. 608.
You can also print a jack to replace the bearings.

You'll need to make some threads:
You need one M3 thread in the levers and one M5 thread in the back side of the shaft.

The levers should have a distance of 120 degree.

Assemble like in the picture.

description.text:
Windmill - vertical with 3 blades.

You can print 3 different models:

  • 1 - No bearing.
  • 2 - Bearing + gear.
  • 3 - Bearing + ring gear.

You can use to light LEDs, recharge batteries or gadgets.

See the videos:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VoFxixnpuf0
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5YYq5SZY8dY

You can help me to do more things like this.__
Buy my designs at pinshape:http://pinshape.com/users/27920-jsirgado
The OpenSCAD file is there, you can change all.

All you need:

  • 3x paper sheet.
  • 1x BBQ stick or threaded rod 4mm diameter.
  • 1x Elastic band(version 1).
  • 1x DC motor 3v to 5v.
  • screws(versions 2 and 3), nuts and washers.
  • 2x 624 bearing 13mm x 5mm x 4mm(versions 2 and 3).

Pieces for version 1:

  • 1x windtop.
  • 6x windarm.
  • 3x windblade_nr.
  • 3x windblade_mr.
  • 1x windwheel.
  • 1x windbase.
  • 3x windfoot.
  • 1x motorwheel.
  • 1x motorbase.

Pieces for version 2:

  • 1x windtop_bearing.
  • 6x windarm.
  • 3x windblade_nr.
  • 3x windblade_mr.
  • 1x windgear.
  • 1x windbase.
  • 3x windfoot.
  • 1x motorgear.
  • 1x motorbase.
  • 2x windbearing.

Pieces for version 3:

  • 2x windtop_bearing.
  • 6x windarm.
  • 3x windblade_nr.
  • 3x windblade_mr.
  • 1x windbase.
  • 3x windfoot.
  • 1x motorgear.
  • 1x motorbase.
  • 1x windringgear.

How to mount the windmill:

  • Glue the windblades and the paper sheets.
  • Join the windarm with the windtops and/or windweel.
  • Fix the windblade set in the windtop and windwhell.
  • Join the windbase with the windfoot.
  • Fix the motor wheel in the motor shaft.
  • Fix the motor in the motorbase.
  • Fix the motorbase in one windfoot.
  • Fix the stick in the base.
  • Put the winblade set in the stick.
  • Adjust the position for the windwheel/windgear/windringgear
    and the motorwheel(version 1) or the motorgear(version 2 and 3).
  • Use the elastic band as a belt(version 1).
  • Adjust the distance of the motor set.
  • Use paper strips and glue to hold the pieces in place.
  • Use paper strips and glue to make the stick stronger.

For the electronics is recommended the use of diode and LM7803 or LM7805 voltage regulator for 3v or 5v respectively.
Go easy with small motors but for big motors you need strong winds to run it.
I am working in an easy motor/generator but no way to finish, test and publish all until the end of the challenge.

title: Make Fixed-base Router into Removable Base

description.text:
This thing allows you to turn a Craftsman fixed-base router into a removable base for jigs, CNC, and other cool stuff.
.
(In my case, for Matthias Wandel's tilting router lift.
http://woodgears.ca/router_lift/index.html)
.
Read the instructions tab before printing.

Tested with Craftsman model 315.269211
.
Caveats:
1) This involves stuffing high-voltage MAINS electrical components into a printed package. DO NOT do this unless you understand and accept the risks!!!
2) Far less important, but still a consideration: The LED module within the base is now disconnected so you have no more light. I never really could see much down there anyway, but if that's a big deal, you might have to come up with some kind of connector.
.
Installation:
1) Unscrew the handle and remove all electronics.
2) Install electronics in the printed enclosure and glue closed.
3) Re-assemble the handle.
4) Slide the enclosure into the slot left behind by the switch.
.
Use:
1) To remove the base of the router, simply slide off the printed part.
2) Then un-screw the height adjustment, depressing the lock pin with a screwdriver (see pics) when it bottoms out.

description.text:
The Discovery spacecraft from Stanley Kubrick's 2001 changed science fiction cinema forever. Nearly all movie spaceships up to that point took their visual language from aircraft; they were smooth and aerodynamic and assumed a gravitational up and down.

The Discovery deliberately ignored that convention. It was designed first and foremost as a vessel for deep space, and its form followed this function. Its long, slender shape would crack under the slightest gravity, but was ideal for keeping the spherical pressure hull of the crew module away from the radioactive power plant and engine. Far from being streamlined, the surface of the Discovery was absolutely covered in panels, pipes, and other mechanical elements that marked it as a complex, working machine.

This revolution in form language has been with us ever since. Even though real spacecraft are actually covered in heat-reflecting mylar and micrometeorite absorbing blankets, film spaceships all have the coating of "greeble" pioneered by Discovery.

I designed this from scratch using only reference images from the movie itself. Scale is about 160 : 1, assembled length 115 cm. Total print time was about 90 hours.

The name of each STL file contains its instructions for printing. The last part after the underscore starts with a number which is the number of times you will need to print that part. There are also optional letters after the number for special instructions. Everything prints in the provided orientation without support unless otherwise indicated.

  • S - needs support
  • P - probably needs support, but may print OK without it
  • M - when printing 2, print one normally and scale the other by -1 to make a mirror image
  • A - part has an alternate, so only one form needs to be used

The parts are designed for a 0.25 inch steel rod as backbone. I used a 36 inch long rod because that's what my local hardware store carries, but a slightly longer one would be better if you can find one. The details are designed to the limit of my printer, about 100 microns, so if your printer is more coarse the model may end up muddy. It was also designed for my small print volume, so it could certainly be scaled up for a larger printer, provided you could find an appropriate rod. Or you could use the thinner rod and print adapters.

The parts can cope with a certain amount of warping. For example the cargo modules (in one alternate) have deeper hollows on the center bottom because the base tends to warp up on the edges so the center is effectively thicker. Other parts have voids and waffle patterns on their bottoms to provide slack. Despite all that warping remains an issue, and some parts will need to be sanded or otherwise adjusted to fit. Use putty to fill gaps and cracks before painting.

comments.text: What a great model! I printed this fine model at 100% in PLA over the last three weeks. I ran into trouble with the supports on the original dish, printed the alternate and it worked fine. I originally printed all the nuts and made 17 mm long spacers to go between them. I then decided to model the spacers and nuts as one piece in Openscad and it made assembly much easier. I will post the nuts/spacer files at some time. The only parts I had to remake were the thrusters, I first printed them at 20% infill and they proved too fragile. Redid them at 50% and they are fine. I used CA glue to build it and it works fine. I did have to ream out the larger parts to get the steel rod to go in . They shrank just enough during cool down to not allow the rod to fit. Overall a great model and one not everyone has.

title: Blow-Powered LED Flashlight
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A mechanically powered flashlight is a flashlight that is powered by electricity generated by the muscle power of the user, so it does not need replacement of batteries, or recharging from an electrical source. There are several types which use different operating mechanisms. They use different motions to generate the required power; such as squeezing a handle, winding a crank, or shaking the flashlight itself. These flashlights can also be distinguished by the technique used to store the energy: a spring, a flywheel, a battery or a capacitor.
(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanically_powered_flashlight)

Now, I made a blow-powered LED flashlight. To turn on a flashlight, you just blow (to force air out through your mouth) it.

The only bad thing is that if you use it too much, you will be dizzy ( just like blowing a balloon too much).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Scr3MMhLoF0

This flashlight is composed of three parts.

  1. Generator
    I got an idea from a brushless dc motor(http://www.westknoxrc.com/index.php/topic,625.0.html?PHPSESSID=cfd709fd8ae2b01adc0d97942767ef77). It is really simple. you need some coils(0.2mm magnetic wire) and two magnets(15mm diameter 4mm thickness).

  2. Vertical Axis Blow Turbine
    It consists of 5 blades. The shape of blades is an arc with 72 degrees( 5 equal parts of a circle).
    Each blade is made by rotating 35 degrees in the center of this arc.
    To blow the flashlight, it has a mouthpiece like the wind instrument.

  3. LED Flashlight
    To light up an LED you need DC 3 volts. So I use "Bridge rectifier" ( for conversion of an AC input into a DC output) and " Joule thief" (for boosting voltage of a low voltage device:http://rimstar.org/sdenergy/joule_thief.htm) circuits.

How it works
When you strongly blow it through the mouthpiece, the vertical axis turbine and the magnets of the generator are rotating together. The shafts of the turbine and generator are directly connected. Then the coils of the generator makes AC(alternating current). The bridge rectifier circuit convert an AC input to a DC output. But the voltage generated by blowing is about DC 0.5~1 volts. To light up an LED you need about DC 3 volts. For boosting voltage, I use Joule thief circuit. Finally LED is lighted. A supercap is used instead of a recharger.

Non-3d-printed parts
Some coils : 0.2mm magnetic wire(10~20m long)
2 magnets : 15mm diameter and 4mm thickness
Bridge rectifier : 4 diodes and 1 supercap.
Joule thief : 1k Ohm registor, 1 npn transistor, 1 Ferrite toroid core, 1 LED, some wires.

All 10 of the Akatsuki rings from the Naruto anime. This one was a bit difficult due to the inconsistency of how the rings are portrayed in the anime, and finding kanji that matched was pretty tricky. Each ring should have a default horizontal inner diameter of about 1.9 cm., with the vertical slightly shortened by the top mantle. Below is a list of each of the rings' respective owners, the ring position, the background color of the ring, and the meaning of the kanji.

Pain: Right thumb, light purple, Rei-zero
Deidera: Right index finger, teal, Ao-blue
Konan: Right middle finger, white, Bya-white
Itachi: Right ring finger, red, Shu-vermillion or scarlet
Zetsu: Right pinky, green, Gai-"boar"
Orochimaru: Left pinky, dark blue, Ku-"sky" or "void"
Kisame: Left ring finger, yellow, Nan-South
Kakuzu: Left middle finger, dark green, Hoku-North
Hidan: Left index finger, orange, San-three
Sasori/Tobi: Left thumb, purple, Gyoku-"jewel" or "ball"

Info is from the Naruto wiki http://naruto.wikia.com/wiki/Akatsuki

Print with a raft and supports. A .3 or below layer height should be good. As with just about any ring, a 50% or above infill should be used. A may also be a good idea to print it 90 degrees from the x-axis to counteract stress from wearing it. Take care when removing the supports. Enjoy!

Rogelia is a small CNC machine, designed using Blender, with a few printed parts. Its main objective is to bring a first contact with CNC technologies in a simple way for students, makers and general public, without messing with more complicated and expensive machines. It was designed and built inside the MECAA project (Máquina Educativa CNC Abierta Argentina): http://es.mecaa.wikia.com

Watch it working:
https://vimeo.com/133936907
https://vimeo.com/132041675
https://vimeo.com/133896122

You'll need:

28BYJ48 STEPPER MOTORS X2
SERVO 9G X1
3D PRINTER AND ABS FILAMENT
THE PARTS (OF COURSE)
7MM LINEAR GUIDES (OF COURSE, YOU CAN MODIFY THE DESIGNS IN ORDER TO FIT THE PARTS)
NYLON STRING (1mm diameter at least)

This is a beta version of a cheap CNC router done in DesignSpark Mechanical CAD.

The concept is that you can either use standard smooth rod and LM12UU bearings or you can use mirror finish stainless steel tubing and a 3D printed bushing insert.

The holes for the guide rods can easily be modified in DesignSpark

It is drawn for NEMA17 steppers.

The spindle mount is drawn with the dimensions of my China knockoff Dremel tool. You should check your own measurements.

I designed it to use m8 but I am seriously considering using m12 threaded rod for the next machine. I am finding a lot of whipping at high speed movements with the m8 stainless rod.

You will have to check the nut size as well.

The bearing at the opposite side of the stepper motor and thread rod is 608zz.

On my last machine I did not secure the opposite end of the threaded rod and allowed it to travel freely without too many issues other than whipping, which I suspect that adding a bearing will only make it bind or introduce resonance.

I would use a high infill and 5-8 perimeter or solid infill for this. It may seem to be over designed but you will see that it is not when you get torque loads on plastic parts.

This is a project I am developing for use in developing countries as a 'vitamin kit' type of low cost machine that can be used to fabricate larger stronger machines and allow entrepreneurs to build a fabrication business the bootstrap method.

I was inspired this design by the now out of business lumen labs CNC.

This puzzle is a derivative of thing:947915 - Snap Together Puzzle. A dodecahedron is to be assembled from 6 pieces instead of 4, and the pieces are of two types instead of all being the same. The puzzle is larger and pieces snap together more securely A key and OpenSCAD code are included.

Print 4 copies of type_01 and 2 copies of type_02 to construct a complete puzzle. The pieces are designed to be printed with support and with the spheres and holes on top. On my Replicator I print them with PLA using 0.3 mm layers and 2 shells. A firm push at the right angle snaps the parts together. The openSCAD code has a number of parameters that can be used to "tweek" the fit. Instructions for using the key are in key.scad.

description.text:
After some gathering with friends who good at music, I know there is a ocean of knowledge behide a simple Guitar Pick.

Difference sound was produced if you use Pick of different kind of thickness. And each shape have its own special usage.

I start to think, why not using 3d printer to make one?
That is how I started this.

Update: Uploaded a new file Shark_V3.STL This is a scale down version after some feed back from my friends

This Pick have thickness of exactly 1mm. It may be too thick to produce soft sound. Please scale the Z-axis to adjust a suitable thickness before printing.

Some testing with my friend found that using 0.7mm is good for PLA.
Did not have chance to do any check with ABS yet.

Catamaran frame for stability – freely rotating wing working as a sail – ball joint connected rudder.
Rarely wind is pushing the sail and sailing upwind is possible with the lift created by the sail. But since we are not able to print a flexible fabric sail, we can print a wing instead.
Frame is the result of experimenting with some different modelling features and is a bit unusual looking.

Modelled with Autodesk Inventor 2014. Planned to enter this to the boat contest but lazy summer days made me miss the deadline. Unfortunately I have not printed this out. My first model for printing purposes, so be merciful. I tried to make the parts printable without supports.
With time I will revise the model and perhaps if the boat floats and sails ok, I will modify it to be included with a couple mini-servos, battery, radio receiver for an easy to control RC-boat.

Wing is connected to the frame with a simple splice that allows the wing to rotate 360 degrees. Its vertical axel is positioned slightly more towards the front of the wing so that the wing should turn itself better towards the wind (in theory). Backside of the wing is flat for printing purposes and to still be able to receive some push from the wind if sailing downwind.
Rudder’s ball joint has been restricted to rotate only horizontally. Hopefully is stiff enough to hold position but still be moved around, I only estimated the tolerance for the joint.
Center of gravity is behind the wing’s vertical axel, this compensates the push from the wing to the front of the frame.

Try a tough plastic like copolyester w/3 external shells and 25% infill.
comments.author: greenail

comments.text: I used PETG and tried the original and something I remixed. They layers split in the planets and they then work their way out. I believe there is a thrust force which pulls them apart under load in this design. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2375124 seems to handle 2x or more load. I saw some layer separation in the race but that is held in check by the fasteners.
comments.author: dentikhval

comments.text: If you have layer separation it's definitely your slicer/printer/filament issue. Your layers are not bonded together well. You should check the extruder temperature, layer height, extrusion width, ambient temperature, retraction settings... Everything. Just take a look at various articles on layer bonding on the web and do some tests with different settings.

This is my first 3D object posted anywhere (but it sure as hell will not be my last) so please be kind in your reviews and comments!
It is a 2CR5 battery housing!
I love my 800si Minolta 35mm camera and still shoot film (35mm and 120) often and these batteries are what it takes!
I had a nasty accident with one of these batteries left in my pocket with some pennies. Luckily I had taken the trousers off to go to bed before the fire broke out so no real harm done!
Anyway, I was annoyed with having to keep them in the big card display they came in, in my bag so made this to prevent any future mishap!

Turn the battery base over (180 degrees) in Cura or whatever slicer you use, so you don't need any support structures and print. I like to print the top and bottom together so I can make sure I have an even number of each! "As you get old the first thing to go is your memory!" I forget who said that but it is very true!
The lid maybe a bit stiff to get on and off for the first couple of fits but after that it should be fine.

Filament guide for filamake filament extruder by 3d-tech
Final version for front bracket holding

Model V100

This is a beaded belt gear for 4.5mm chain that clamps onto a 5mm NEMA17 motor shaft using an ordinary hose clamp. It's designed to use a flat on the motor's shaft, but you can change that in the source files provided to fit just about anything.

Print, clean up, file a flat on the motor's shaft if necessary. Fit the hose clamp loosely over the collet. Put the thickest quadrant of the collet over the flat on the shaft, and push the gear onto the shaft - the hole tapers. When it's at the right level, just do up the hose clamp. The gear will be held in place quite securely.
In PLA the hose clamp may crush the collar, or may simply foul on the surroundings. In that case, just epoxy it onto the drive shaft.

description.text:
Derivative of a toy.  Challenges the idea that nostalgia must be bought back from corporations...
I've tried to make this file parametric.  The idea was to have the gripper and handle resize automatically depending on the dimensions of the arms.  That kind of was implemented but you will have to play with some hard coded values to make it work properly.  I could use some help with this if anyone is up to it. I'd like to make it snap together as well...

Use 1.75 MM filament as hinges. (Unless you are editing the .scad file)  Just melt the tip a bit and press it into a flat surface while it is still hot to create a pin.  After it is in place melt the other side and repeat.
This should be easily printable on a makerbot provided the holes are small (the size they are in the stl should work fine) or your bridge settings are tuned. 
You will have to mirror the gripper part depending on how you assemble the arms.  You want the thin side of the gripper to be on the same side that the bar is.  Ie if you are attaching it to the top arm, the top of the gripper should be thin. This part needs to be mirrored along 2 axises to make both gripper parts. If you are looking at it arranged as it is in the picture it would need to be mirrored along the x and z axis.  I'm probably overcomplicating it though. Just look at the picture...
If you have an UP you are in luck. I have included the files I used to print this.  Just use the .up3 files and you won't have to worry about mirroring at all...  
Added WilliamAAdams' much more elegant parametric bar code under the title GripperBar.  It is much easier to read and understand.  I will be editing this some more to reduce the amount of plastic used and add quick snap in connectors...

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:148722

tolerance = 0.2
font_spacing = 0.81
word = CHIARA
object = 2
helper_tabs = 0
inner_length = 125

I finished building a rather large Delta Type printer a few months ago
I needed something that could handle any one of my HotEnds
Some are store bought but many are hand made
When I looked for a Effector assembly I found many, each quite good and effective
But none truly fit the bill
I didn't want the HotEnd dangling beneath and I needed room for a large range of hotend girth
Hoping to be useful, I want to share what I have created

Now get to work ... Let me know your thoughts!

Let your imagination flow!

Just to stop confusion
In the two multi color images that RED block to the rear is a 40mm FAN. It is affixed via the screw holes provided:
one(1) hole on each POST ( left & right ) and two(2) holes on the CAP ( each cap has them )

The fans AIRFLOW is directed inward towards the center via the spherical relief that is found in the structure of the two POSTs and Cap.

I've been using this assembly for 3 months solid now without any problems, by SOLD I mean I use my printers at home 24/7 just as the my office machines.

If you look at the photos of the actual machine, yes I'm using a RJ45 keystone to facilitate quick change out of my hotends between machines
I found a common hotend harness arrangement sometime ago

description.text: This is a little design I've come up with for a 3D-printed car assembly, download it and let me know what you think! Each part is made with a plastic expansion gap for the Makerbot Replicator 2X using PLA plastic (which usually expands by about 1% on an unheated platform). Enjoy.

As my Prusa Air type DIY Reprap has the Z motors mounted on the lower side, I needed to somehow "anchor" the threaded Z-rods with a 608 ball bearing on the upper panel.  So this is a simple frame to fixate a ball bearing on a flat surface.  The frame is attached with 4 screws (I just used 2) to the panel, whereas the ball bearing itself is simply "snapped" into the frame.  
The provided files are dimensioned for the standard 608ZZ type ball bearing, but the scad file can easily be configured for other types of ball bearings.

comments.text: What you actually need, is to let the threaded rod move around as it feels like, and let the smooth rod do the steering of the axis instead.

comments.text: I agree to your point if the Z-motors are top mounted.  However, with bottom mounted Z-motors, I am afraid that the wobbling tends to get worse, since in this case a) the "free" part of the Z-rods is usually much longer (assuming that most of the time we work at small Z values) and b) gravity increases the wobbling.

author: 3DModularSystems

title: Dyson DC59 Nozzle Adaptor for Vacuum Bags

description.text:
This adaptor is designed to allow the Dyson DC59 (and similar) hand vacuum cleaner to be used to suction "space bags" (clothing storage bags). Since these vacuum cleaners have a protruding piece that stops the nozzle from sealing flush with the space bag nozzle, you can't get a proper seal without this piece.

I have uploaded two designs:
One is a basic nozzle with no special features, which can be used as a starting point for making other adaptors and vacuum tools.
The second has a restraining key (to stop the tool from rotating freely), vent holes (to allow a small amount of airflow, preventing the vacuum from pulsing as it senses low airflow), and a rotating vent cover (which allows you to adjust the amount of air flow passing)

I'd like to see if anyone else uses these as a basis for other vacuum cleaner attachments.

Side note: I didn't bother doing the experimentation required to properly size the vent holes (i.e. drill test holes in the non-vented attachment to see how big the hole had to be to prevent pulsing), so the two longer slots are larger than required.
Based on testing with the new model ("space bag attachment - with breather"), you need an orifice of about 75mm² area to allow sufficient air flow to prevent the dyson pulsing off due to low flow. this is equivalent to having the second smallest breather half-covered.

1. Print the "space Bag attachment - with breather". No support material required
  2. Assembly by sliding the vent cover over so that the raised boss fits into the ring groove on the attachment
  3. Insert into the vacuum cleaner, slotting the raised key into the slotted restraint on the top side of the vacuum cleaner nozzle
  4. With all vent holes covered, suction the space-bag
  5. As airflow drops off, the vacuum cleaner should pulse on and off (it doesn't like running at no-flow). Rotate the ring to allow a small amount of air to pass, adjusting as necessary (too little, and the vacuum will pulse. To much, and you won't get sufficient vacuum to further compress your space-bag).

description.text:
Because different hole spacing in circulation I have even uploaded the four most common. The total length is 117mm and usually you can install 6 inch props. The length from motor mount middle to first frame mount hole middle is 80mm. And in this version there are two motor mounting dimensions.

You can see in the picture which is A and which is B (frame mount dimensions M3)

Motor mount dimensions:
11,8mm - 16,2mm M2 (1804 1806)
15,8mm - 19,2mm M3 (2204 2206)
Inner hole dimension:
6,5mm (1804 1806)
9,0mm (2204 2206)

Not for 3D printing but for CNC (normaly 3mm carbon)

You can send an appropriate company and then gets the right part. My Favorite in Germany is actually https://noblish.com

Wegen der verschiedenen Lochabstände die im umlauf sind, habe ich die 4 meist verbreiteten Maße hochgeladen. Die Gesamtlänge ist 117mm und normal auch noch für 6 Zoll Props geeignet. Die länge von Motormitte bis zur Mitte erstes Frame Montageloch ist 80mm. Und in dieser Version gibt es auch zwei verschiedene Motormontage Maße.

Im Bild kann man sehen welches Maß A und B ist (Frame Montagelöcher M3).

Maße Motormontage:
11,8mm - 16,2mm M2 (1804 1806)
15,8mm - 19,2mm M3 (2204 2206)
Maß Innenloch:
6,5mm (1804 1806)
9,0mm (2204 2206)

comments.text: Is there a way to convert these to a .STL or .OBJ file? They look great!
comments.author: UnfortunateFish

comments.text: yes you can do. but i don't want to upload so much files. You can load FreeCAD and do it yourself. if you have freecad and fcstd downloaded you can open it. Now you select in the top left "model", then you can choose your prefered arm. with a double click you can change under the spot "length", the thickness of the arm. Then you go to "view"> "workbench"> "mesh design". Then on "meshes"> "create mesh from shape"> under "mesh options" click "standard"> click "OK". Now you can with a "right click" on the new "mesh" export the arm. Standard is an STL File. if that's too difficult for you, send me an email with your wish. Then I will send you the file or files. [email protected]

description.text:
Deco Cover for M8 Nut/Bolt

Designed to fit the printed M8 nut included in this project. Doubles as light duty thumb wheel for craft projects.

If your printer flares out the first layer a little, you may need to trim the opening for the cover to fit. I had to do this to about 25% of the ones I printed.

If you want to print M8 bolts to go with this cover, one is included. If you want matching bolts you can get a couple from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:911293

This cover is a little loose on a real M8 nut, but a spot of glue would do the trick. I'd guess a scale of 99% would take out the slop if using a real nut.
Untested design, unscaled (its huge) Work in Progress!!
For my bud Jeramy. His address. Go to his house and tell him I said hi! The font is Trebuchet - my favorite medieval siege weapon and font.

It is recommended to grind the contact areas there the phone slides in.

Inspired by the great T-Rex Shower Head http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:329596 i remixed mcallaghan95´s dragon bust for my garden bathpool.

As i used Autodesk Inventor to rework the .stl i had to reduce the original files polygon count by ca. 90%.

I plan to ad some led lights so the water gets colored.

Dragon was printed in red ABS and colored with silver an blue paint.

Addition 05.Aug.15
Just uploaded a bigger version, with 200mm on the largest side.
Holes are the same as small version.
Also added a (very) small channel for installing two led lights.
Actually i not know if this really will work.
Print was very good, but i´m out of time at the moment so i can test it in about two weeks.

Dragon head
3 shells
25% infill
0.2mm layer height

Adapter
3 shells
40% infill
0.2mm layer height
It´s should fit a 1 1/4" garden hose, as the diameter of the mounting adapter is 31mm.

Parts need support

You also need 6x M6x16 screws and some sealing for the space between head and adapter. I used two component silicone as sealing, but

This is my first serious FreeCAD design. If you are interested in learning how to make more complex shapes, I highly recommend watching some videos on FreeCAD to learn about sketches and constraints. This stand is nothing like my first (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:745209) , and has a more curved appearance, but uses a lot more plastic. (V2 was so bad when I tried to use it that I didn't publish it).

While I'm very happy with this, I may try another design that tries a bit harder to limit the plastic consumption :)

Print shown is PLA, 2mm layer height, .4mm nozzle on my Prusa i3 chinese clone kit (Aurora Z605). Print time in this configuration was 12 hours and 16 minutes, and it used about 150g of plastic.

Just be careful about bed placement, as it just fits on an 8"x8" heated bed.
I tried to make a airtight seal for plastic bottle and garden hose. I will test it :) Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/eE18zEzkjQp

A bald, piratey adventurer! Just a model I did of character in the story my wife and I are writing.

Can print without supports, but with might be a little cleaner.

EDIT: Now 2 versions - one ~4 inches tall that stands without a base, and one ~1.5 inches tall, with a base and a little nub under the chin for printing without supports (can easily be clipped off after print).

I have made slight variation on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5699 Now it is possible to make wider range of bricks, plates and tiles.

Set hollow_knob parameter to true to make knobs hollow.
Set circular_hole parameter to true to make circular holes like in standard Technic plates.
Set flat_top parameter to true to get rid of the knobs and add a groove to the bottom, so that the blocks could be separated. Set reinforcement to false if you want to make 1xN or Nx1 bricks without pins. Set it to true to have pins. The meaning remains the same for other sizes. EXAMPLES: standard LEGO 2x1 tile without pin
block(1,2,1/3,reinforcement=false,flat_top=true);
standard LEGO 2x1 flat with pin
block(1,2,1/3,reinforcement=true);
standard LEGO 2x1 brick with pin
block(1,2,1,reinforcement=true);
standard LEGO 2x1 brick without pin
block(1,2,1,reinforcement=false);
standard LEGO 2x1x5 brick has no pin and has hollow knobs
block(1,2,5,reinforcement=false,hollow_knob=true);

comments.text:
I think it never worked, solid_bottom is set 'true' by default. If you change this to 'false' in libraries/MCAD/lego_compatibility.scad (line 59) it works.
Or you have to add it to every block you make. Example: block(1,2,1, solid_bottom=false);

remixed_from.title: YALFE - YET ANOTHER LYMAN'S FILAMENT EXTRUDER

remixed_from.author: Cos
remixed_from.title: YALFE V2 - YET ANOTHER LYMAN'S FILAMENT EXTRUDER V2

title: MO.RE.SYS. 3D (YALFE 3)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Yep!

It is finally here...
Modular Recycling System for 3D printers.
It includes:
-shredder for plastics
-filament extruder
-filament puller
-filament spooler
..all in one package. These subsystems are on independent bases
so you can store them with ease. They interconnect by placing them side-by-side. The spooling is under the main extruding system to free space and facilitate the filament winding system with tension.

Features:
-plastics shredder, manually or motor driven
-filament extruder with extruding speed variation, pulling with speed variation, FILAMENT FLOW SENSOR that stops the system when it recognizes if the filament is no more extruding for any reason, filament spooling with speed variation and winding system with tension, so you have a dense spooled filament on the spool.
-fume absorber and elimination with the use of active carbon filter
-hopper cooling to eliminate any chance of melting the hopper

Specs:
extruding speed :12 cm/min
tolerance: +- 0.3mm
materials: all known (PLA,ABS,PE,PP,NYLON, etc),
also can extrude all fancy filaments (wood, metal, etc, just mix PLA or ABS with any material powder you want at 10~30%)
of course can accept coloring pellets to color your filament.

max spooling length: 200mt or 2,2 kilos (depends your spool size and the coke hopper). can run many many hours

Energy consumption: 350W peak, 150W/h average

final testing material: ABS, BASF TERLURAN GP22
testing time: 25,5 hours non stop
extruded filament: ~180mt

it is strongly recommended to use the filament sensor on you printer, (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:454584), If you use filament produced by this system in order to eliminate any fluctuations on filament's diameter. The sensor is very accurate and can cope with insane diameter variations (from 3mm to 1,5mm in 1 cm difference)

i am still documenting the project, so any info found here is incomplete.

Again a big thanks to Hugh Lyman for making me believing that i can make a home filament extruder on my own.

It uses the following things :

-Mini shredder by Filamaker:
eshop : http://filamaker.eu/product/mini-shredder/
files : https://grabcad.com/library/mini-shredder--1
manual : http://issuu.com/marcusthymark/docs/user_manual_mini_shredder
although i made it myself, i strongly encourage you to buy it.You will save much much time....
-spool holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29526
-L-bracket http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2226
-parts of Lyman's different extruder versions:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34653
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:145500
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:380987
note:for the spool winder pawl and lead (Lyman extruder V, sheet A07, part#8 & #9), you dont have to make them by yourself,
i have already files ready for print. instead of lead you just use
a pile of cents
-Herringbone gear set (thnx Scribblej!)
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6544
-parts of popcorn lamp
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:344846
-Lift Off Hinge
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19522

more instructions, boms, and electrical drawings to come...

Part of a ongoing project scanning the heads of bloggers, artists, DIYers, makers, musicians, hackers and anybody else we think is notable.
Made with a Polhemus 3d scanner at MakerBot.

In early 90s I opened a bottle of coke, I took the ring that was holding the cap, I inverted the ring and put it on the cap. Now, when I have a 3d printer, I took 12 bottles and Autodesk Inventor...
This device has positive effect on blood circulation.

You will need 4 standard bottle caps and 12 under-cap rings from one famous company.
  • Drill at least 5.5mm (6.0 at most) holes in the centers of the caps.
  • Next, turn the rings inside out and put three of them on each cap. Those diameters match exaclty.
  • Use 3D printer to make 1 holder, 1 axis and 2 inserts.
  • Assemble, enjoy...

author: hyperair

description.text:
Customize it to fit your magnet(s) and you key ring.
It has a cylindric hole in the middle.
Pause the print to insert your magnets.
For example:
I print the first layer at 0.3mm and all the others at 0.2mm.
I selected a base of 0.7mm so it's 3 layers.
I used 4 magnets, 1mm thick each (4/0.2=20). I paused the print at 4.7mm (at the 23rd layer), right before the first layer of solid infill and placed the magnets.
Resume as quickly as you can. If you delay the two layers won't stick together.

I was asked to print an oxygen wrench and could only find one on the internet (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:897996/), but I didn't like the design. I think it's a marvelous looking object, but I have my doubts about how well it will hold up over time. So I whipped up some test objects for dimensioning, then added a quick handle. v2 will be more refined.

Update 8-2-15: I had too much time to play yesterday, and went through three more iterations. I tried a number of different designs, but found (as always) that simple is better. v4 is a slimmed down version of v1 with a horizontal and vertical slot. I had to increase X and Y by 2.5 percent to get a loose fit. At 100% size it was a snug fit on most of the bottles I tried, but I only have 7 on hand at the moment.

I suggest printing O2 Wrench Test 2 first and checking for fit. Then determine how much to scale and apply that to the full size wrench.

description.text:
Inspired by DaVinci's flying machine, I made this finger operated model. You can either use your thumb, pointer, and middle finger or your middle three fingers to operate it. The pictures do not include the tail piece.

Here is the thing in action: https://youtu.be/rAEp2KCDNiA

I pondered how to make the wings more.. winglike while still being easily printable. I thought this two part design with a connector looked pretty cool so I stuck with it.

I plan to make a display stand so that the wing could be operated through gears and a crankshaft, rather than fingers.

I included two main stl files with everything on them for eases of printing. I also included all the individual parts.

Assembly is pretty straightforward;just check out the model in thingiview if you have problems.

Printed with PLA on the Replicator dual on a glass plate.

description.text: Made with PrintShop MedalMaker

{
"scalar" : 1,
"bottomText" : "SCIENTIST",
"topText" : "EXPERT",
"currentBase" : 6,
"currentCoin" : 16,
"typeID" : 0
}

This 3D print icon is derived from a digital capture of the famous Sinai version of Christ Pantocrator -- the oldest known icon of its type, located in Saint Catherine's Monastery. The locations of key parts of this design -- such as the hand raised in blessing, the Holy Gospel, the parts of the face, and the halo -- are taken from measurements of the digital print. For more information about the Christ Pantocrator icon: http://www.pallasweb.com/ikons/ikon-gallery/christ-pantokrator-from-sinai.html

There are two similar designs to download -- one with a place to attach a hook, and one without. The former can be used to make a bag tag or Christmas ornament. See the instructions for more details.

(Note: On the left side of the design, on His right shoulder, there is something not quite right with the STL file, and the print has a small hole on the top of the shoulder. I have not found a way to fix this flaw.)

The STL has been scaled and adjusted to these dimensions: X = 65mm, Y = 34,69mm , Z = 4.7mm

On the Replicator 2, using these settings -- No raft, 15% infill, 0.15mm resolution -- the print takes about 40 minutes.

For the three-color version:
Blue (base): 0% - 46%
Silver (through end of robe): 46% - 93%
Gold (hand and book): 93%-100%

If you want to try a version with many colors (e.g. only the halo is gold), see the original icon in the link in the description.

remixed_from.title: Parametric fast-clamp OpenSCAD library for K8200/3Drag

title: Fast-clamp mount, transfoms K8200/3Drag in CNC milling machine using Valex drill. update 03

description.text:
A fast and simple Valex drill mounting system, using the library fast-clamp for 3Drag/K8200 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:936871
notes:
a) the original fast-clamp design is here modified in 2 places: a more elastic clamp and a strengthened click part.
b) due to space constraints, I used 2 knok-in nuts (see photos and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30576 ).
c) Parts of this support can be used to fix the drill horizontally: to do so screw the two ring parts into a wooden tablet.

Drill axis can be vertical or horizontal: see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:964001

version Drill_Clamp03
Added:
1) a system to fix accessories (dust cleaner, ligth...) into the bottom ring: using magnet or screw.
2) a new module, coupling(), base part for accessories.

Complete collection of Add-on for 3Drag/K8200 using Fast Clamp: http://www.thingiverse.com/sillano/collections/3drag-fast-clamp-addon

• requires the Valex adapter http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:936831 so print it.
  • print all 3 + 2 parts
    (tested using PLA, layer 0.2, perimeter 6 layers, infill 80%-100%)
  • use the M4 threaded rod and 2 self-locking nuts to tie the noose and link parts.
    Attention to parts position.
  • use 2 standard M4 screws, washer, lock washer and nuts to fix the bottom ring.
  • use 2 screws M4 with small head, lock washer, and 2 M4 knok-in nuts, using a soldering iron to fix it (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30576)
  • use 2 screws and nuts to close the rings.

If you wish to print separate parts, use netfabb Basic (free) to cut stl file in parts long the axes.

Instruction ver 03:
as ver 02, plus:

  • You do not need to print the new module "coupling()". You can use it in your custom applications.

Extra:

  • threaded rod M4, 80 mm long, 2 washers and 2 self-locking nuts (for click)
  • screws: 2 x M4 phillips round pan head, 12 mm long, 2x M4 lock washer, and 2 M4 knok-in nuts (top ring)
  • screws: 2 x M4, 20 mm long, 4 x M4 washer, 2x M4 lock washers, and 2 M4 nuts (bottom ring)
  • screw: 2 x M4 , 26 mm long, 4 x M4 washer, 2x M4 lock washers, and 2 M4 nuts

Extra (ver 03)

  • A magnetic closet door.
  • A socket set screws – 5x15, used to fix the magnet into bottom part.
  • A knok-in nuts M4.
  • 2 pop rivets 3mm.

Modifications (scad file)
To use the drill-clamp03.scad file, you need also the library fast-clamp05.scad, added here for your convenience.

  • use coupling(true) to get magnetic joint
  • use coupling(false) to get screw joint

title: Adjustable Pocket Hole Jig with Vise

description.text:
Adjustable Pocket Hole Jig with Vise

For assembly you need the following:
1 Screw rod of aprox 100mm - 112mm long
2 bolt
epoxy
2 1/4 copper coupling

Printed using PLA with 0.250-0.300mm layer height and 25% infill

For jig adjustment glue with epoxy the thread rod and the nut to the base.

For the pocket hole jig with a solder iron place the nut inside the hole and place the two couplings inside the drilling holes to prevent damage of the drill bit to the PLA plastic

comments.text: I like this and really want to make one for myself, but the print size is a little too big.  Two pieces, the vice base and the screw are over 140 mm so i'm trimming 10 mm out of the vice, looks like it should still be good for a standard 2x4, and I'm taking a little more out of the knob on the screw and replace the knob there with one 10 mm thick.  Hopefully it prints great and works cause I'm building a wall in a garage this weekend.

title: Diffuser for Panasonic GF2 built-in flash

description.text:
Diffuser for Panasonic GF2 Micro Four Thirds mirrorless camera.  
This is very compact and fit to the built-in flash.  
I'm not sure you can use this design for Panasonic GF1 or GX1. These cameras seem to have same built-in flash but I don't have both of them. I guess you can't use this for GF3 or later.  
This design is based on Chu's triangular version of "Canon Speedlight 580EX II Flash Diffusers". Thank you for the original work.

I have printed with ReplicatorG and use "Clip" option of skeinforge.
If you turn off "Clip", you will get a quality problem. Clear PLA and 0.27mm layer resolution gave good results.
